title: Multi-focus - dog fur QDA scores 2 boxplots

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Many veterinarians use the condition of a dog’s fur as an indicator of the dog’s overall health. A researcher is investigating the healthiness of the coats of fur for dogs from a certain population. The healthiness of the dog’s fur is evaluated using a quantitative description analysis (<math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where a veterinarian uses a standard process to rate the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs. From previous studies, the population distribution of the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the fur of dogs is roughly uniform with mean <math alttext="mu equals 52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>52</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 36" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Compare the shapes of the sampling distributions of the sample mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for random samples of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs and for random samples of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population. Explain your answer.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Many veterinarians use the condition of a dog’s fur as an indicator of the dog’s overall health. A researcher is investigating the healthiness of the coats of fur for dogs from a certain population. The healthiness of the dog’s fur is evaluated using a quantitative description analysis (<math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where a veterinarian uses a standard process to rate the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs. From previous studies, the population distribution of the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the fur of dogs is roughly uniform with mean <math alttext="mu equals 52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>52</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 36" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Compare the shapes of the sampling distributions of the sample mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for random samples of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs and for random samples of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population. Explain your answer.

(b) Which of the following would be more likely to obtain from the population?• A random sample of <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs having a mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score that is greater than <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>or• A random sample of <math alttext="81" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>81</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs having a mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score that is greater than <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>Justify your answer.

The researcher conducted a study to investigate whether a new supplement is different in promoting healthy coats of fur for dogs than the existing supplement. The researcher randomly assigned <math alttext="70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from a local animal shelter to receive one of the two supplements, with <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving the new supplement and <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving the existing supplement. At the end of the study, a veterinarian, who was not aware of each dog’s assigned supplement, determined the <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for each dog. The results of the study are shown in the following boxplots. (c) Based on the boxplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the dogs who received the new supplement and the dogs who received the existing supplement.

The researcher will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that the mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score is different for dogs receiving the new supplement rather than the existing supplement.(d) Name the appropriate hypothesis test and state, in words, the hypotheses.

Assume the conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="93" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the difference in the mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for dogs (new supplement minus existing supplement) was calculated to be <math alttext="negative 5.514 plus or minus 6.156" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.514</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>6.156</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based only on this confidence interval, is the difference in the mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores statistically significant? Justify your answer.
(f) Can the findings of this study be generalized to all dogs? Explain why or why not.

topic.text: 1.9: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
